ai-mn21:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn21:2.1_0: Now at that time, Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot was mixing too closely together with the nuns.
ai-mn21:2.3_0: if any mendicant criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
ai-mn21:2.4_0: And if any mendicant criticized Phagguna of the Top-Knot in their presence, those nuns got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
ai-mn21:2.5_0: That’s how much Phagguna of the Top-Knot was mixing too closely together with the nuns.
ai-mn21:3.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha,
ai-mn21:3.2_0: “Sir, Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot mix closely together with the nuns.
ai-mn21:3.4_0: if any mendicant criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
ai-mn21:3.5_0: And if any mendicant criticized Phagguna of the Top-Knot in their presence, those nuns got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
ai-mn21:3.6_0: That’s how much Phagguna of the Top-Knot was mixing too closely together with the nuns.”
ai-mn21:4.1_0: Then the Buddha addressed a certain mendicant:

ai-mn21:4.4_1: He went to Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot and said to him:
ai-mn21:4.6_2: He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
ai-mn21:5.1_0: “Is it really true, Phagguna, that you’ve been mixing overly closely together with the nuns?
ai-mn21:5.3_0: if any mendicant criticizes those nuns in your presence, you get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?
ai-mn21:5.4_0: And if any mendicant criticizes you in those nuns’ presence, they get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?
ai-mn21:5.5_0: Is that how much you’re mixing overly closely together with the nuns?”
ai-mn21:5.7_0: “Phagguna, are you not a gentleman who has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness?”
ai-mn21:6.1_0: “As such, it’s not appropriate for you to mix so closely with the nuns.
ai-mn21:6.2_0: So if anyone criticizes those nuns in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life.
ai-mn21:6.3_0: If that happens, you should train like this:
ai-mn21:6.4_0: ‘My mind will remain unaffected. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
ai-mn21:6.6_0: So even if someone strikes those nuns with fists, stones, rods, and swords in your presence,

ai-mn21:6.10_0: So if anyone criticizes you in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life.

ai-mn21:6.13_0: So Phagguṇa, even if someone strikes you with fists, stones, rods, and swords, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life.

ai-mn21:7.1_0: The Buddha said to the mendicants,
ai-mn21:7.2_0: “Mendicants, I used to be satisfied with the mendicants.
ai-mn21:7.4_0: ‘I eat my food in one sitting per day.
ai-mn21:7.5_0: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-mn21:7.6_0: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.
ai-mn21:7.7_0: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’
ai-mn21:7.8_0: I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;
ai-mn21:7.9_0: This is what should be done by me, mendicants, I reconcile with them.
ai-mn21:7.10_0: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
ai-mn21:7.11_0: Then a deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
ai-mn21:7.12_0: In the same way, I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;
ai-mn21:7.13_0: This is what should be done by me, mendicants, I reconcile with them.
ai-mn21:7.14_0: So, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.
ai-mn21:7.15_0: You will achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
ai-mn21:8.1_0: Suppose that not far from a town or village there was a large grove of sal trees
ai-mn21:8.2_0: that was choked with castor-oil weeds.
ai-mn21:8.3_0: Then along comes a person who wants to help protect and nurture that grove.
ai-mn21:8.4_0: They’d cut down the crooked sal saplings that were robbing the sap, and throw them out. They’d clean up the interior of the grove,
ai-mn21:8.5_0: and properly care for the straight, well-formed sal saplings.
ai-mn21:8.6_0: In this way, in due course, that sal grove would grow, increase, and mature.
ai-mn21:8.7_0: In the same way, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.
ai-mn21:8.8_0: You will achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
ai-mn21:9.1_0: Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a housewife named Vedehikā.
ai-mn21:9.3_0: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is sweet, even-tempered, and calm.’
ai-mn21:9.4_0: Now, Vedehikā had a bonded maid named Kāḷī who was skilled, tireless, and well-organized in her work.
ai-mn21:9.6_0: ‘My mistress has a good reputation as being
ai-mn21:9.8_0: But does she actually have anger in her and just not show it? Or does she have no anger?
ai-mn21:9.9_0: Or is it just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?
ai-mn21:9.10_0: Why don’t I test my mistress?’
ai-mn21:9.11_0: So Kāḷī got up during the day.
ai-mn21:9.12_0: Then the housewife Kāḷī said to me,
ai-mn21:9.15_0: ‘You’re getting up later in the day—what’s up with you, girl?’
ai-mn21:9.16_0: ‘That’s not easy for what it is.’
ai-mn21:9.17_0: ‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up in the day!’ Angry and upset, she scowled.
ai-mn21:9.19_0: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
ai-mn21:9.20_0: She just has well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?
ai-mn21:9.21_0: Why don’t I test my mistress?’
ai-mn21:9.22_0: So Kāḷī got up later in the day.
ai-mn21:9.23_0: Then the housewife Kāḷī said to me,
ai-mn21:9.26_0: ‘You’re getting up later in the day—what’s up with you, girl?’
ai-mn21:9.27_0: ‘That’s not easy for what it is.’
ai-mn21:9.28_0: ‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she blurted out angry words.
ai-mn21:9.30_0: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
ai-mn21:9.31_0: She just has well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?
ai-mn21:9.32_0: Why don’t I test my mistress?’
ai-mn21:9.33_0: So Kāḷī got up later in the day.
ai-mn21:9.34_0: Then the housewife Kāḷī said to me,
ai-mn21:9.37_0: ‘You’re getting up later in the day—what’s up with you, girl?’
ai-mn21:9.38_0: ‘That’s not easy for what it is.’
ai-mn21:9.39_0: ‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up even later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she grabbed a rolling-pin and hit Kāḷī on the head, cracking it open.
ai-mn21:9.40_0: Then Kāḷī, with blood pouring from her cracked skull, denounced her mistress to the neighbors,
ai-mn21:9.41_0: ‘See, ladies, what the sweet one did!
ai-mn21:9.42_0: See what the even-tempered one did! See what the calm one did!
ai-mn21:9.43_0: How on earth can she grab a rolling-pin and hit her only maid on the head, cracking it open, just for getting up late?’
ai-mn21:9.44_0: Then after some time the housewife Vedehikā got this bad reputation:
ai-mn21:9.45_0: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is fierce, ill-tempered, and not calm at all.’
ai-mn21:10.1_0: In the same way, a mendicant may be the sweetest of the sweet, the most even-tempered of the even-tempered, the calmest of the calm, so long as they don’t encounter any disagreeable criticism.
ai-mn21:10.2_0: But it’s when they encounter disagreeable criticism that you’ll know whether they’re really sweet, even-tempered, and calm.
ai-mn21:10.3_0: I don’t say that a mendicant is easy to admonish if they make themselves easy to admonish only for the sake of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ai-mn21:10.5_0: Because when they don’t get robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, they’re no longer easy to admonish.
ai-mn21:10.6_0: But when a mendicant is easy to admonish purely because they honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching, then I say that they’re easy to admonish.
ai-mn21:10.7_0: So, mendicants, you should train yourselves: ‘We will be easy to admonish purely because we honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching.’
ai-mn21:11.1_0: Mendicants, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.
ai-mn21:11.6_0: from a mind of hate, or from hate.
ai-mn21:11.8_0: They might defend truthfully or falsely.
ai-mn21:11.10_0: They’d say what’s beneficial or what is unbeneficial,
ai-mn21:11.11_0: Whether or not you immerse others in samādhi, you should say,
ai-mn21:11.12_0: Then you should train like this:
ai-mn21:11.13_0: ‘Our minds will remain unaffected. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
ai-mn21:11.14_0: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
ai-mn21:12.1_0: Suppose a person was to come along carrying a spade and basket
ai-mn21:12.3_0: ‘I shall make this great earth be without earth!’
ai-mn21:12.4_0: And they’d dig all over, scatter all over, spit all over, and urinate all over, saying,
ai-mn21:12.7_0: Could that person make this great earth be without earth?”
ai-mn21:12.10_0: Because this great earth is deep and limitless.
ai-mn21:12.11_0: It’s not easy to make it be without earth.
ai-mn21:12.12_0: That man will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

ai-mn21:20.1_0: Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb, anyone who had a malevolent thought on that account would not be following my instructions.

ai-mn21:21.1_0: If you frequently reflect on this advice—the simile of the saw—
ai-mn21:21.2_0: do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”
ai-mn21:21.4_0: “So, mendicants, you should frequently reflect on this advice, the simile of the saw.
ai-mn21:21.5_0: This will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
ai-mn21:21.6_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn21:21.7_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
